Today, before our current and still new publishing year
progresses any further, we state here some guiding NewsLetter principles for the illumination and future reference of
our readers;
The first function of the News-Letter, like that of any
reputable newspiaper, is to inform, and like any newspaper,
we are supported by a community to perform this service.
The community the News-Letter serves, the undergraduate
student body, like every community supporting a newspaper,
puts the paper it supports under the obligation to print all
of the community's news, whether good or bad, and without
favoritism to any organization or individual.
Therefore, we hasten to remind certain individuals and
certain organizations that the advertisement of campus social
and athletic events is not our sole "raison d'etre"; that
omission is one way of telling an untruth; that suppression
gives rise to rumors, often proving to be far more damaging
than would have been the publication of the facts; that the
knowledge that "unfavorable publicity to the Hopkins" results
from the conscientious reportage by the News-Letter of the
facts of an unsavory situation is an effective deterrent to any
rash actions willfully contemplated by an individual or organization, or perhaps resulting from insufficient forethought—
at any rate, we hope it helps to instill on campus a "think twice"
attitude.
The last statement above hints at a secondary duty that
accompanies a newspaper's primary function, i.e., to inform.
This secondary duty is to mold public opinion.
We try to mold campus opinion in two ways. The first is,
as already mentioned, by presenting a complete and objective
reportage of the news. By objectively rePorting the complete
facts we help the community we serve form its own judgments
as to the right or wrong of a situation.
The second way we mold campus opinion is, of course,
through these editorial columns and featur,e pages. In analyzing, interpreting and commenting here upon the week's news
we strive for a position closely akin to our ideal of complete
objectivity in news reports, that of being observers completely
independent of any and all external pressures.
However, we realize that we can be wrong in our observations. Hence we have a standing invitation to our readers
to point out our errors, to offer constructive criticism, suggestions, refutations and rebuttals, whether by a meeting with
the News-Letter Board of Control, or through our correspondence columns, if ,circumstances warrant it, we even will be
more than happy to print here signed "guest editorials."
Finally, nut-shelling our policy and at the same time offering, if we may, still an added ramification (a ramification
somewhat slightly and sadly lacking here today) we would
like to quote a statement of the late William Allen White
—a statement of which we as collegiate journalists are rather
fond •

While we intend to pass no judgment on the wisdom of the
Dormitory Student Representative Council decision to outlaw
the presence of women in students' rooms, we are not a little
concerned about the slipshod manner in which this action was
taken. The DSRC, contrary to the apparent wish of their
constituents, instituted the regulation, in a manner which seems
parallel to the benevolent dictatorships, where laws are pa.ssed
for the good of the people even if without their consent. But
the action was taken with no attempt on the part of the DSRC
to point out to dorm residents its merits. It was, rather, assumed
that no intelligent discussion could come of an open hearing.
The bill was railroaded through without giving the students a
chance to air their views. Even if some nebulous "pressure from
above" was being exerted—which seems doubtful—the DSRC
does not have the right to avoid discussion ... to forget that
they are nothing more than representatives.

Fritz Lehman's "Hoffner" is in
the twentieth century Mozart
idiom. The orchestra is large,
probably at least seventy-five

if I should disagree with Jochum's

not let that defer me from Mr.
Lehman's brilliant performance.
Both are at least very good; the
Lehman is, in my opinion, a gem.

Homewood, Baltimore, October 8, 1954

Jay Gridders Meet Carnegie In Second Game Tomorrow
GRIDIRON GANDER

Johns Hopkins' footballers tomorrow trek to •Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, to tangle with the Carnegie Tech Tartans. This is the second game of the season for the
Hopkins eleven and the third for
Tech.

Hopkins' 1954 football season may not be successful, but it
should definitely be interesting. According to Coach John Bridgers,
who's certainly in a position to know, the Jays have their
toughest schedule in many years ahead of them. And reports from
the schools themselves—although such notices do tend to exaggerate somewhat—back up Bridgers' observation to a disturbing
degree. In almost-unanimity, they praise their school teams as
"the best in recent years," "the strongest in history," and
so on, until the reader begins to wonder whether poor old Johnny
Hopkins shouldn't disband its team and concede defeat before

Hopkins Mentor John Bridgers
hopes his squad can get on the
winning path, but at the same
time he rates Carnegie as the
toughest opponent on a schedule
"which has no breathers."
Carnegie, coached by Dr. Eddie
Baker, a dentist, has what Baker
calls his best team yet. He has
coached the Tartans since 1946
according to JHU scouting reports.
The Pennsylvanians boast a big,
rough line and an "elephant"
backfield.

By HOWARD WASKOW
Sports Editor

of the kind. For one thing, even a doddering Johnny wouldn't
think of giving up the ghost without at least token resistance.
And in the second place, the Johnny of 1954 isn't poor and isn't

No one expected the Blue Jays to make as good a showing
for as long a time as they did last Saturday. Certainly no one
expected them to jump out to a 19-14 lead in the third quarter
and force the Pennsylvanians to come from behind for their
41-19 victory. The second half collapse was expected; or if it
wasn't, it should have been. The Black and Blue simply didn't,
and don't, have the man-power and the depth to compete
successfully with comparative powerhouses like F and M. Carnegie Tech, Hathpden-Sydney, Randolph-Macon, and so on down
the JHU schedule.
As we said before, the season will in all likelihood be a
losing one; but it will have its exciting moments. There will be
crowd-stimulating plays, like Jack Lawrence's 80-yard touchdown
gallop last week; there will be outstanding seasonal performances,
perhaps by newcomer Jimmy Dunn, of whom Bridgers says,
"With time, he may be the finest end ever to play at Hopkins."
The JHUers, with what Bridgers claims is a "much
stronger" first team than last year, will probably win a couple
of games, maybe even several. In the other contests, lack of
reserves—which lack almost invariably brings weariness and
sloppy play—will make the difference between winning and losing,
&s it made the difference against F and M.
SOCCER SCENE
Soccer coach, Mickey Cohrane, highly hopeful about his
team's chances to successfully defend its 1953 Mason-Dixon title,
is putting much of his faith in the performance of Goalie Dave
Hack. Hack, the six-foot-three-inch co-captain who has been
flirting with All-American honors for the past two years, seems
to get better with each sea-son. His great plays of last year—
plus the work of now-graduated Jim Hutchins and Stan Henry
—spurred the Jays to the Middle-Atlantic championship final,
where they were beaten by Drexel, the only team to score with
any degree of frequency against Hack.
And Coach Cochrane says the big goalie is even better this
year. We don't see how he can get much better; but if he is,
then JHU pitch fails are in for some of the finest college goaltending they've ever seen.
FRESHMAN OUTLOOK
Reports from observers of Freshman pre-season practices
lead standers-by to conclude that the yearlings as a whole are
particularly strong this year.
The Freshman footballers particularly have come in for
laudatory notices. According to the latest rumors, Freshman
Coach Bob Scott has a powerhouse on hand. If the reports
are true—and Hopkins observers will be able to witness the first
real test of their validity on October 22, when the Frosh open
against the Baltimore Junior College—then much of the credit
for building the team must go to Varsity Coach Bridgers and
the rest of the football staff. Bridgers and his cohorts have spent
many hours in tracking down in-town and out-of-town high school
gridders who are also capable of living up to Hopkins' academic
standards. It can't have been an easy job.

electro-optical processes has

Today, before our current and still new publishing year
progresses any further, we state here some guiding NewsLetter principles for the illumination and future reference of
our readers;
The first function of the News-Letter, like that of any
reputable newspiaper, is to inform, and like any newspaper,
we are supported by a community to perform this service.
The community the News-Letter serves, the undergraduate
student body, like every community supporting a newspaper,
puts the paper it supports under the obligation to print all
of the community's news, whether good or bad, and without
favoritism to any organization or individual.
Therefore, we hasten to remind certain individuals and
certain organizations that the advertisement of campus social
and athletic events is not our sole "raison d'etre"; that
omission is one way of telling an untruth; that suppression
gives rise to rumors, often proving to be far more damaging
than would have been the publication of the facts; that the
knowledge that "unfavorable publicity to the Hopkins" results
from the conscientious reportage by the News-Letter of the
facts of an unsavory situation is an effective deterrent to any
rash actions willfully contemplated by an individual or organization, or perhaps resulting from insufficient forethought—
at any rate, we hope it helps to instill on campus a "think twice"
attitude.
The last statement above hints at a secondary duty that
accompanies a newspaper's primary function, i.e., to inform.
This secondary duty is to mold public opinion.
We try to mold campus opinion in two ways. The first is,
as already mentioned, by presenting a complete and objective
reportage of the news. By objectively rePorting the complete
facts we help the community we serve form its own judgments
as to the right or wrong of a situation.
The second way we mold campus opinion is, of course,
through these editorial columns and featur,e pages. In analyzing, interpreting and commenting here upon the week's news
we strive for a position closely akin to our ideal of complete
objectivity in news reports, that of being observers completely
independent of any and all external pressures.
However, we realize that we can be wrong in our observations. Hence we have a standing invitation to our readers
to point out our errors, to offer constructive criticism, suggestions, refutations and rebuttals, whether by a meeting with
the News-Letter Board of Control, or through our correspondence columns, if ,circumstances warrant it, we even will be
more than happy to print here signed "guest editorials."
Finally, nut-shelling our policy and at the same time offering, if we may, still an added ramification (a ramification
somewhat slightly and sadly lacking here today) we would
like to quote a statement of the late William Allen White
—a statement of which we as collegiate journalists are rather
fond •

While we intend to pass no judgment on the wisdom of the
Dormitory Student Representative Council decision to outlaw
the presence of women in students' rooms, we are not a little
concerned about the slipshod manner in which this action was
taken. The DSRC, contrary to the apparent wish of their
constituents, instituted the regulation, in a manner which seems
parallel to the benevolent dictatorships, where laws are pa.ssed
for the good of the people even if without their consent. But
the action was taken with no attempt on the part of the DSRC
to point out to dorm residents its merits. It was, rather, assumed
that no intelligent discussion could come of an open hearing.
The bill was railroaded through without giving the students a
chance to air their views. Even if some nebulous "pressure from
above" was being exerted—which seems doubtful—the DSRC
does not have the right to avoid discussion ... to forget that
they are nothing more than representatives.

NEWS-LETTER

Homewood, Baltimore, October 8, 1954

Jay Gridders Meet Carnegie In Second Game Tomorrow
GRIDIRON GANDER

Johns Hopkins' footballers tomorrow trek to •Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, to tangle with the Carnegie Tech Tartans. This is the second game of the season for the
Hopkins eleven and the third for
Tech.

Hopkins' 1954 football season may not be successful, but it
should definitely be interesting. According to Coach John Bridgers,
who's certainly in a position to know, the Jays have their
toughest schedule in many years ahead of them. And reports from
the schools themselves—although such notices do tend to exaggerate somewhat—back up Bridgers' observation to a disturbing
degree. In almost-unanimity, they praise their school teams as
"the best in recent years," "the strongest in history," and
so on, until the reader begins to wonder whether poor old Johnny
Hopkins shouldn't disband its team and concede defeat before

Hopkins Mentor John Bridgers
hopes his squad can get on the
winning path, but at the same
time he rates Carnegie as the
toughest opponent on a schedule
"which has no breathers."
Carnegie, coached by Dr. Eddie
Baker, a dentist, has what Baker
calls his best team yet. He has
coached the Tartans since 1946
according to JHU scouting reports.
The Pennsylvanians boast a big,
rough line and an "elephant"
backfield.

By HOWARD WASKOW
Sports Editor

the games are even played.
Well, Johnny Hopkins is of course not going to do anything
of the kind. For one thing, even a doddering Johnny wouldn't
think of giving up the ghost without at least token resistance.
And in the second place, the Johnny of 1954 isn't poor and isn't
old. As a matter of fact, off last week's performance against
Franklin and Marshall, he seems to be a surprisingly sturdy

In last week's 41-19 Jay loss to Franklin and Marshall, Diplomat
ball-carrier CARL BLAIR is about to be tackled by Hopkins fullback
ED MESKO, No. 42, and tailback ED LAWRENCE, No. 47. Approaching to help out in downing BLAIR are HERB COHEN, No. 64, DON
GALLAGHER, No. 51, and ARLYN MARSHALL, No. 22. JIM PARK,
No. 70, has just missed a diving attempt to tackle the Pennsylvanian.

young man.
No one expected the Blue Jays to make as good a showing
for as long a time as they did last Saturday. Certainly no one
expected them to jump out to a 19-14 lead in the third quarter
and force the Pennsylvanians to come from behind for their
41-19 victory. The second half collapse was expected; or if it
wasn't, it should have been. The Black and Blue simply didn't,
and don't, have the man-power and the depth to compete
successfully with comparative powerhouses like F and M. Carnegie Tech, Hathpden-Sydney, Randolph-Macon, and so on down
the JHU schedule.
As we said before, the season will in all likelihood be a
losing one; but it will have its exciting moments. There will be
crowd-stimulating plays, like Jack Lawrence's 80-yard touchdown
gallop last week; there will be outstanding seasonal performances,
perhaps by newcomer Jimmy Dunn, of whom Bridgers says,
"With time, he may be the finest end ever to play at Hopkins."
The JHUers, with what Bridgers claims is a "much
stronger" first team than last year, will probably win a couple
of games, maybe even several. In the other contests, lack of
reserves—which lack almost invariably brings weariness and
sloppy play—will make the difference between winning and losing,
&s it made the difference against F and M.
SOCCER SCENE
Soccer coach, Mickey Cohrane, highly hopeful about his
team's chances to successfully defend its 1953 Mason-Dixon title,
is putting much of his faith in the performance of Goalie Dave
Hack. Hack, the six-foot-three-inch co-captain who has been
flirting with All-American honors for the past two years, seems
to get better with each sea-son. His great plays of last year—
plus the work of now-graduated Jim Hutchins and Stan Henry
—spurred the Jays to the Middle-Atlantic championship final,
where they were beaten by Drexel, the only team to score with
any degree of frequency against Hack.
And Coach Cochrane says the big goalie is even better this
year. We don't see how he can get much better; but if he is,
then JHU pitch fails are in for some of the finest college goaltending they've ever seen.
FRESHMAN OUTLOOK
Reports from observers of Freshman pre-season practices
lead standers-by to conclude that the yearlings as a whole are
particularly strong this year.
The Freshman footballers particularly have come in for
laudatory notices. According to the latest rumors, Freshman
Coach Bob Scott has a powerhouse on hand. If the reports
are true—and Hopkins observers will be able to witness the first
real test of their validity on October 22, when the Frosh open
against the Baltimore Junior College—then much of the credit
for building the team must go to Varsity Coach Bridgers and
the rest of the football staff. Bridgers and his cohorts have spent
many hours in tracking down in-town and out-of-town high school
gridders who are also capable of living up to Hopkins' academic
standards. It can't have been an easy job.
